answers.answer: An enlarged heart is just what the name suggests --- portions of the heart are larger than normal due to overworking to compensate for heart desease (e.g., congestive heart failure, propr heart attack). The ventricles thicken or the atria dilate. I have an enlarged atria as a result of high BP over the years and some mitral valve regurgitation. It's easily detected in an x-ray or an echo, both of which you have already had. So your doc would have already detected any sign of enlargement. You appear to have a normal heart. Try not to worry about things that may happen in the future.Best wishesTony

If you're not feeling well, despite the battery of tests you've gone through, perhaps it means there's something entirely different the matter ... perhaps something not even necessarily all that serious, but chronic and distressing.What that may be is something you'll need to consider carefully, and perhaps it'll mean seeing yet another doctor ... but perhaps a different kind of doc than the heart specialists you've apparently been to. Maybe it would be as simple as seeing your internist or GP again.In my case, my symptoms were all over the map, and often subtle enough that I had doctors dismiss my concerns as "You're just getting older," or worse. In truth, I have Hashimoto's Disease, causing a condition called hypothyroid. Runs in the family, but I wasn't even aware of that fact. Turns out that blood tests (many) spread over a decade all showed it clearly, but the docs never bothered to tell me. Once discovered (by a physician's assistant, who actually LOOKED at the stinkin' blood tests), treatment was thyroid hormone replacement. The synthetic ran about $15 a month, and the (to my way of thinking much better) natural thyroid (derived from pigs) is less than $4 a month.I'm not suggesting you have a thyroid problem, of course, but merely trying to illustrate an example.You may already have the evidence in hand, in all those blood tests. To cite another example, a colleague of mine had cancer. She beat it, but continued feeling awful. Finally, one day she happened to ask her oncologist if -- when she ordered all those blood tests -- they ever tested for blood sugar. "Sure," she was told, but they'd never bothered looking at that. "Well," my friend asked, "what's my blood sugar at?" 600, and she was instantly sent to an endocrinologist and put on diabetes treatment. (Bet SHE often thought she might have heart issues too, given all the symptoms of untreated diabetes).Are your symptoms limited to the chest area, and include sharp pains or the like? Could also be such things as muscle strain (yes, this is true!) of the pecs, gas, and similar problems. Again, so long as you can find a doc who won't brush you off as a chronic whiner -- something they did to me, in what I consider blatant malpractice -- if your problem is of this order, it shouldn't be hard to eventually track down.

va_tony - your info isn't accurate.leealee: I had an enlarged heart.  Mine was caused by pregnancy.  Usually it is due to cardiomyopathy, high blood pressure, drug abuse, or atheletes heart.  In some cases, like cardiomyopathy, a cause is obvious (coronary artery disease or pregnancy) and in some cases no cause is identifiable, but it's usually suspected that a virus causing myocarditis preceeded it.  For some people, obvious high blood pressure for many years can lead to heart enlargement, as can obesity.  Chronic arrhythmias such as uncontrolled a-fib or 20,000 PVCs a day for a few months or years can do it also.If you're healthy, have normal blood pressure, do not have any symptoms (weakness, short of breath, palpitations) then there is no reason to think you have heart enlargement and it's best to put this out of your mind.  It's not rare, but it's always attributable to something.  In many cases, it is also reversible with removal of the cause (blood pressure reduction, arrhythmia control, resolving the cardiomyopathy, etc.).Don't let this worry you.

I really truly don't think so.  A Holter would show abnormalities too, most likely.  You don't seem to have any risk factors.  Enlarged hearts are associated with disease of the heart, it doesn't just happen.  Hang in there, and for now, try to scratch this one off the worry list ;)
